description: From Latin malleātus, perfect passive participle of *malleō (“beat with a hammer”), related to malleus (“a hammer, mallet”).

adjectives.description: malleate (comparative more malleate, superlative most malleate)

entries.meaning: (zoology) Possessing or resembling a malleus, or another structure shaped like a hammer.
(malacology, of a shell) Having a surface with shallow round indentations, resembling copper that has been hammered.

verbs.description: malleate (third-person singular simple present malleates, present participle malleating, simple past and past participle malleated)

entries.meaning: (rare) To beat into shape with a hammer.
